title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing quantity as 5 units and/or does not explain that the 5th unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($80) is greater than the marginal cost ($70); the firm will not produce the 6th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($90) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($80).

The response identifies the profit-maximizing quantity as 5 units and explains that the 5th unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($80) is greater than the marginal cost ($70); the firm will not produce the 6th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($90) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($80).

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the number of firms in the industry will decrease and/or does not explain that negative economic profit will cause firms to exit the industry.
The response states that the number of firms in the industry will decrease and explains that negative economic profit will cause firms to exit the industry.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the market price will increase and/or does not explain that with the exit of firms, the market supply will decrease, causing the price to increase.
The response states that the market price will increase and explains that with the exit of firms, the market supply will decrease, causing the price to increase.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the demand for kaleidoscopes will decrease and/or does not explain that the negative cross-price elasticity of demand for kaleidoscopes with respect to the price of Good N means that the goods are complements; therefore, an increase in the price of Good N will lead to a decrease in the demand for kaleidoscopes.

The response states that that the demand for kaleidoscopes will decrease and explains that the negative cross-price elasticity of demand for kaleidoscopes with respect to the price of Good N means that the goods are complements; therefore, an increase in the price of Good N will lead to a decrease in the demand for kaleidoscopes.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does none of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good N will stay the same in the short run and explain that property taxes are a fixed cost and a change in fixed cost does not affect the marginal cost.

· States that the deadweight loss will stay the same and explain that a price floor below equilibrium is not binding and will not affect the quantity exchanged in the market.

The response does one of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good N will stay the same in the short run and explain that property taxes are a fixed cost and a change in fixed cost does not affect the marginal cost.

· States that the deadweight loss will stay the same and explain that a price floor below equilibrium is not binding and will not affect the quantity exchanged in the market.

The response does both of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good N will stay the same in the short run and explain that property taxes are a fixed cost and a change in fixed cost does not affect the marginal cost.

· States that the deadweight loss will stay the same and explain that a price floor below equilibrium is not binding and will not affect the quantity exchanged in the market.
